title: 110_hr5714
content:
The "United States Army Commemorative Coin Act of 2008" recognizes the significant role of the United States Army in protecting freedom since its founding in 1775. The Act aims to honor the sacrifices of American soldiers through commemorative coinage, as the Army is the nation's oldest and largest military service branch without such recognition. The National Museum of the United States Army will be the Army's only service-wide, national museum honoring all soldiers since 1775. It will be located at Fort Belvoir, Virginia, near the Nation's Capitol, and will be supported by the Army Historical Foundation dedicated to preserving the history and heritage of American soldiers. The National Museum of the United States Army, supported by the Army Historical Foundation, aims to educate future Americans about the sacrifices of American soldiers and preserve Army history through various initiatives. The Army Historical Foundation supports the National Museum of the United States Army and is actively involved in a capital campaign for its development. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint $5 gold coins in honor of the Army's founding in 1775. The coins minted under this Act shall weigh 8.359 grams, have a diameter of 0.850 inches, and contain 90 percent gold and 10 percent alloy. $1 silver coins shall weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper. Half dollar clad coins shall weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and be minted to specific specifications. These coins are legal tender and may also be considered numismatic items. The coins minted under this Act shall have designs emblematic of the traditions and history of the United States Army, with specific inscriptions and motifs honoring American soldiers. The coins minted under this Act shall honor American soldiers, be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant parties, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities using different mint facilities. The Secretary may issue coins minted under this Act during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2011. The coins will be sold at a price including face value, surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted before issuance. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES.
    (a) Sales of coins minted under this Act will include surcharges:
        (1) $35 per $5 coin
        (2) $10 per $1 coin
        (3) $5 per half dollar coin
    (b) Surcharges received will be paid to the Foundation for the National Museum of the United States Army.
    (c) The Foundation will be audited for the amounts received.
    (d) No surcharge may exceed specified amounts. Limitation on surcharges: No surcharge may be included for issuing any coin under this Act if it would exceed the annual commemorative coin program limit. The Secretary of the Treasury can provide guidance on this.
